classification.name: Personally Identifiable Information
classification.desc: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('Data Subject'); an identifiable person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identification number or to one or more factors specific to his physical, physiological, mental, economic, cultural or social identity.

asset.name: Personally Identifiable Information
asset.desc: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('Data Subject') an identifiable person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identification number or to one or more factors specific to his physical, physiological, mental, economic, cultural or social identity.

classification.name: Personally Identifiable Information
classification.desc: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person ('Data Subject'); an identifiable person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identification number or to one or more factors specific to his physical, physiological, mental, economic, cultural or social identity.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-799
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-799: Improper Control of Interaction Frequency The product does not properly limit the number or frequency of interactions that it has with an actor, such as the number of incoming requests. This can allow the actor to perform actions more frequently than expected. The actor could be a human or an automated process such as a virus or bot. This could be used to cause a denial of service, compromise program logic (such as limiting humans to a single vote), or other consequences. For example, an authentication routine might not limit the number of times an attacker can guess a password. Or, a web site might conduct a poll but only expect humans to vote a maximum of once a day.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Cache error pages according to HTTP standard
countermeasure.desc:
Proper configuration of CDN policies to cache error pages according to HTTP standards is crucial for mitigating the impact of Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. By strategically configuring your CDN, you can ensure that error pages are cached appropriately, thus reducing the load on the origin server during periods of high traffic caused by potential attacks.

  • Review HTTP Status Codes: Start by reviewing the HTTP error status codes that are most likely during a DoS attack, such as 500, 502, 503, and 504. Configuring your CDN to manage and cache these statuses appropriately can significantly alleviate the server load.
  • Set Cache-Control Headers: Configure your origin server to send the correct Cache-Control headers for error pages. This guidance instructs the CDN on which error responses should be cached and for how long. Consider headers such as Cache-Control: public, max-age=60, stale-while-revalidate=30 to optimize caching behavior.
  • Custom Error Pages: Design custom error pages to be served from the cache. Implementing custom pages reduces the frequency with which the CDN needs to request error pages from the origin server, especially during high-load conditions.
  • Configure TTL (Time-to-Live): Determine and configure the appropriate Time-to-Live (TTL) for cached error pages in your CDN. The TTL should be adapted based on anticipated traffic fluctuations and how often the information needs updating. This helps balance server load reduction with serving users current content.
  • Test Configuration: Regular testing of your CDN configuration is imperative. Ensure the effectiveness of your error caching policies by simulating DoS conditions. This allows performance monitoring and necessary adjustments to settings, ensuring robustness against real attacks.

By implementing these strategies, your CDN will be better equipped to relieve your origin server during potential DoS attacks, ensuring service continuity and availability for legitimate users.

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enable the CDN's built-in bot blocking feature
countermeasure.desc:
To protect your Content Delivery Network (CDN) from malicious automated traffic, the implementation of bot filtering mechanisms is essential. This guide walks you through activating and configuring these mechanisms effectively:

  1. Access the CDN Management Console: Begin by logging into your CDN provider's management console. Ensure that your user account has the necessary permissions to modify security and filtering settings.
  2. Enable Bot Filtering: Within the security settings section, locate the options related to bot management or traffic filtering. Enable the bot filtering feature, ensuring it's set to actively monitor and filter bot traffic.
  3. Configure Detection Sensitivity: Adjust the bot detection sensitivity to strike a balance between filtering out unwanted bots and allowing legitimate traffic. Start with default configuration and fine-tune based on ongoing traffic analysis and insights.
  4. Define Rules and Policies: Establish detailed rules that identify unwanted bot activities. Include parameters such as request rate limits, reputation-based IP filtering, and signature-based detection for precise policy formulation.
  5. Enable Rate Limiting: Set up rate limiting for specific CDN resources or endpoints to control request frequency. This can help prevent resource abuse by bots and reduce the risk of service disruption.
  6. Implement Blacklisting and Whitelisting: Configure automatic blacklisting of known harmful IP addresses while maintaining a whitelist of approved, trusted sources. Regularly update these lists using threat intelligence insights.
  7. Monitor and Analyze Traffic: Leverage the CDN’s analytics capabilities to track traffic patterns. Regularly check logs for unusual activity, which may suggest attempts to bypass filters or highlight areas where filtering rules need tweaking.
  8. Regular Updates and Maintenance: Ensure bot filtering rules and algorithms are kept up-to-date. Adapt to new threats by staying informed about emerging bot activity patterns and making necessary adjustments to your filtering strategy.

Following these steps will help you effectively utilize your CDN’s bot filtering capabilities, safeguarding your platform from bot-related threats while ensuring a seamless experience for legitimate users.

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enable the CDN's Web Application Firewall (WAF)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance your application’s security posture against SQL injection attacks, utilize the Web Application Firewall (WAF) feature provided by your CDN. Follow these steps to effectively deploy and configure the WAF:

  • Access the CDN Management Console: Log in to your CDN provider's management console where you can access the security settings and WAF features.
  • Enable the WAF: Navigate to the security settings section and enable the WAF feature. This may be under a specific tab or menu labeled “Security” or “Firewall.”
  • Choose a Predefined Security Policy: Select from available predefined policies that include SQL injection protection. These policies are created to quickly protect against common attack vectors and should include rules targeting malicious SQL patterns.
  • Customize Rules (Optional): If necessary, customize the rules to match the specific needs of your application. This can be done by adding exceptions or modifying existing rules to better fit your application’s logic.
  • Create Alert Mechanisms: Configure alerting mechanisms to notify your security team when a potential SQL injection attack is detected. This could be done via email alerts, dashboard notifications, or integrations with SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) systems.
  • Test the Configuration: Conduct thorough testing to ensure the WAF configuration is valid and effectively blocking SQL injection attempts without affecting legitimate traffic. Utilize both automated testing tools and manual testing methods.
  • Monitor and Adjust: Regularly monitor the WAF logs and adjust the rules as needed based on the evolving threat landscape and patterns of false positives or negatives.

By following these guidelines to configure your CDN's WAF, you can significantly reduce the risk of SQL injection attacks and protect your application's data integrity. Ensure that updates and patches are applied promptly as they become available from the CDN provider to maintain robust security.

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools
SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

countermeasure.name: Ensure encryption mechanisms are in place for CDN
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data security within a CDN, implementing encryption protocols like HTTPS and TLS is crucial for safeguarding data in transit. These protocols help prevent unauthorized interception and protect sensitive information as it travels between clients and servers. Here’s how to effectively implement these encryption protocols within your CDN:

  1. Obtain SSL/TLS Certificates: Acquire valid SSL/TLS certificates from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA). This step is essential for establishing encrypted connections.
  2. Configure HTTPS on Servers: Ensure that your CDN is properly configured to support HTTPS. This involves installing the SSL/TLS certificates on your servers and enabling the HTTPS protocol to handle all incoming and outgoing traffic.
  3. Enforce HTTPS Connections: Configure your CDN to redirect all HTTP traffic to HTTPS. This can typically be done via server settings or through HTTP headers like HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to ensure that all communications utilize the encrypted channel.
  4. Implement TLS for Data Exchanges: Ensure that your CDN supports the latest versions of the TLS protocol for all data exchanges. This enhances the security of communication over the network by using robust cryptographic techniques.
  5. Regularly Update Protocol Configurations: Periodically review and update protocol settings to use the strongest cipher suites and disable obsolete ones. Staying updated with the latest security recommendations helps protect against known vulnerabilities.
  6. Verify Encryption Across Endpoints: Regularly test your CDN's endpoints to ensure that encryption is consistently applied across all points of data transit, protecting data integrity and confidentiality.
  7. Monitor and Audit Network Traffic: Continuously monitor network traffic for signs of attempted data interception or other malicious activities. Implement logging and auditing processes to ensure transparency and prompt response to potential threats.
  8. User Education and Awareness: Educate end-users on the importance of using secure connections and validating HTTPS in their browsers. This can prevent attacks like man-in-the-middle (MITM) that exploit unsecured channels.

By following these steps, you can enhance the security of data transmitted through your CDN, protecting it against interception and ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of the information exchanged.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial of service (DoS) attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers perform a Denial of Service (DoS) attack, exhausting resources and disrupting service availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may leverage botnets or other automated tools to continuously send a high volume of traffic to the CDN, overwhelming its ability to manage incoming requests.
Impacts
The primary impacts include service downtime, increased latency for users, potential loss of revenue, and reputational damage for the service provider.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a network of compromised machines to flood the CDN with traffic, causing legitimate user requests to be delayed or dropped. This results in poor user experience and may drive users to competitors' platforms.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could exploit weaknesses in communication channels to intercept and access sensitive data being transmitted, compromising its confidentiality.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals who are positioned between the client and the CDN can utilize tools to eavesdrop or alter data transmissions, capitalizing on unsecured connections or outdated security protocols.
Impacts
This could lead to unauthorized access to sensitive information, data breaches, loss of user trust, and potential legal repercussions.
Example Attack Scenarios
During data transmission, an attacker could intercept communication between a user and the CDN, accessing sensitive information such as login credentials or financial information without detection.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: SQL injection attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers exploit vulnerabilities within a web application's database layer, enabling them to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data and systems by injecting malicious SQL code.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Bad actors utilize SQL injection techniques by entering malicious SQL statements into input fields or manipulating query strings exposed within a web application.
Impacts
Successful exploitation can lead to data breaches, system compromise, and data manipulation or destruction, resulting in significant operational and financial damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker inputs a specially crafted SQL statement into a login form, bypassing authentication mechanisms and gaining administrator-level access to the web application's backend database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply IAM policies to restrict access to cloud functions
countermeasure.desc:
Define and implement IAM policies that ensure GCP Cloud Functions are invoked only by authorized users and services. Use the principle of least privilege to grant the minimal set of permissions necessary for each user, service, or application. Regularly review and audit IAM policies to confirm that access is properly restricted and aligned with business needs, and that unnecessary permissions are removed. This control helps protect cloud functions from unauthorized access and potential misuse.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Assign a unique service account to each cloud function
countermeasure.desc:
Configure each GCP Cloud Function to use a unique service account to limit the scope of access and privileges. This practice ensures that each function operates with a dedicated identity, restricting access to only the resources necessary for that specific function. By isolating service accounts, you minimize the risk of privilege escalation and prevent the misuse of elevated permissions across multiple functions. Regularly audit the service accounts and their associated roles to ensure they follow the principle of least privilege.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Cloud Functions Identity Best Practices

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all cloud function endpoints to encrypt data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all GCP Cloud Function endpoints are configured to use HTTPS to secure data transmission and prevent interception. This control mandates the use of encrypted communication channels, ensuring that any data exchanged between your cloud functions and external services is protected from unauthorized access or tampering. Review and configure function triggers to ensure they enforce HTTPS and reject HTTP traffic. Regularly audit your functions to confirm compliance with this security requirement.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Cloud Functions Security Documentation

ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Store and retrieve secrets securely using Google Secret Manager
countermeasure.desc:
Use Google Secret Manager to securely store and manage sensitive information such as API keys, credentials, and tokens. Configure GCP Cloud Functions to retrieve secrets securely at runtime, ensuring that sensitive data is not hardcoded or exposed in environment variables or code. Regularly audit and rotate secrets to minimize the risk of compromise, and ensure that access to secrets is restricted to only authorized functions or users.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Secret Manager Best Practices

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access control on functions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate access control on GCP Functions can allow unauthorized users or services to invoke functions, potentially leading to data exposure, service misuse, or unauthorized access to sensitive cloud resources. Misconfigured IAM policies or broad permissions can increase the risk of such attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised accounts.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak IAM policies, using over-privileged accounts or services to invoke cloud functions, or brute-forcing unsecured function endpoints.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data, resource exploitation, and service disruptions.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to an over-privileged service account and uses it to invoke a sensitive cloud function, exfiltrating data.
  2. A malicious insider with overly broad permissions invokes internal cloud functions to manipulate business-critical processes without detection.

threat.name: Improper use of shared service accounts for functions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Using shared service accounts for multiple GCP Functions can expose sensitive resources to broader access than necessary, increasing the risk of unauthorized access or privilege escalation. Shared service accounts may accumulate more permissions over time, leading to potential misuse.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, or compromised services.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting overly-permissive service accounts used by multiple functions, or compromising a function that has broad access due to a shared service account.

Impacts

  • Privilege escalation, unauthorized access to sensitive resources, data breaches, and potential service disruption.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A compromised cloud function with access to a shared service account is used by an attacker to escalate privileges and access sensitive data in other services.
  2. An insider with access to a shared service account misuses elevated permissions to modify critical cloud infrastructure across multiple functions, bypassing security controls.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description
Transmitting data between GCP Functions and other services without encryption exposes sensitive information to interception by attackers. Unencrypted communication channels, such as HTTP, allow malicious actors to eavesdrop, manipulate data, or carry out man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, network eavesdroppers.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted data over HTTP or other unsecured communication protocols, exploiting weak or misconfigured transport layer security.

Impacts

  • Data breaches, loss of confidentiality, unauthorized access, and data manipulation.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A GCP Function sends sensitive data to an external API over HTTP instead of HTTPS, allowing an attacker to intercept and steal the data using a packet sniffer.
  2. An attacker performs a man-in-the-middle attack on unencrypted traffic between cloud functions, modifying the data in transit to manipulate the service behavior.

threat.name: Insecure management of secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper management of secrets, such as API keys, credentials, or tokens within GCP Functions, can lead to unauthorized access if they are exposed or compromised. Storing secrets in unsecured locations, such as environment variables, increases the risk of leaks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting secrets stored in function environment variables, code repositories, or logs, or intercepting unsecured secrets during transmission.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to cloud resources, data breaches, and potential manipulation of services or databases.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A cloud function stores API keys in environment variables, which are accessed by an attacker exploiting a vulnerability in the function, leading to unauthorized access to external services.
  2. A developer inadvertently pushes secrets to a public repository, allowing an attacker to use the compromised secrets to access critical cloud resources.

weakness.name: CWE-1039
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1039: Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category, but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different, incorrect concept.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-703
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-703: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions The product does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the product.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

countermeasure.name: Acknowledge incidents when investigation starts
countermeasure.desc:
When investigating the cause of an incident in GCP Monitoring, it is crucial to follow a systematic approach to ensure all necessary steps are taken for efficient incident management. Acknowledging an incident when you begin the investigation process is a key step in this procedure. This action helps to signal to your team and system that the incident is under active review and prevents duplication of efforts.

Steps to acknowledge an incident:

  1. Access Google Cloud Monitoring Incident Overview via the Google Cloud Console.
  2. Navigate to the "Incidents" section where you can view all open incidents.
  3. Select the specific incident that you are beginning to investigate.
  4. From the incident details page, click on the "Acknowledge" button. This action marks the incident as acknowledged, indicating it is being actively investigated.
  5. Monitor any changes or updates in the incident's status and proceed with further investigation as required.

By acknowledging the incident, teams implement an effective process for incident management that aligns with the security guidelines for GCP Monitoring. This step helps maintain clarity on incident status and ensures structured communication within the team.

For additional information on handling incidents, visit the following resources:

  • Incidents and Events Documentation
  • Alerting Concepts

countermeasure.name: Configure alerting policies for quick notifications
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the countermeasure of ensuring policies are set to alert soon after an uptime check failure is detected, follow these steps:

  1. Create Uptime Check:

    Begin by setting up an Uptime Check for your desired resource. This is essential to monitor the availability and performance of your service.

    Refer to the official documentation for detailed steps on creating an Uptime Check: Create synthetic monitors.

  2. Configure Alerting Policies:

    Once you have an Uptime Check in place, you need to configure alerting policies that will trigger alerts soon after a failure is detected. Ensure that the conditions are appropriately set so that any unforeseen downtime is promptly addressed.

    Find more guidance on configuring uptime alerting policies here: Uptime alerting policies.

  3. Understand Alert Labels and Incidents:

    As you set up your alerting policies, it's crucial to incorporate clear incident labels and understand how incidents are managed. This will enhance your ability to respond effectively.

    Detailed information can be found here: Alert labels and Incidents and events.

  4. Review Access Controls:

    Ensure only authorized personnel have the capability to modify alerting policies. This is vital for maintaining the integrity of your monitoring setup.

    Review access control guidelines here: Access control.

By following these steps, you can enhance your monitoring reliability and ensure timely alerts to mitigate any service interruptions effectively.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Do not insert sensitive data into configurations
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively implement the countermeasure of avoiding sensitive information placement in labels or metadata, a cloud engineer should adhere to the specified guidelines from the GCP Monitoring service documentation. Here is a step-by-step guide:

  1. Understand the Purpose of Labels and Metadata: Labels and metadata within GCP Monitoring are primarily intended for categorization, organization, and filtering of monitored resources. Sensitive data such as personal information, credentials, or proprietary business data should not be included in these fields.

  2. Configure Access Control: Implement and regularly review Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to monitoring resources and their metadata. Proper configuration of IAM policies can help mitigate risks associated with unauthorized data exposure. More information on access control can be found in the GCP Monitoring access control documentation.

  3. Data Classification and Handling: Encourage the use of data classification and proper handling procedures for all team members who manage GCP resources. Regular training and updates on data sensitivity can reduce the likelihood of inadvertent exposure.

  4. Utilize Built-in Tools for Data Management: GCP Monitoring offers various tools and settings for managing data effectively. Engage these tools to audit and cleanse existing labels and metadata of any sensitive information. More details on compliance and data management can be found at GCP Monitoring compliance documentation.

By following these steps, cloud engineers can effectively mitigate risks associated with the exposure of sensitive information within GCP Monitoring services.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Grant access with IAM as needed
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure only authorized access to monitoring data, careful management of IAM roles is crucial. This process involves specifying precise access permissions for resources under GCP Monitoring. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Identify Required Access Levels: Review the roles and permissions required for your team members. Determine the minimal permissions needed for each individual's role, adhering to the principle of least privilege. For guidance on specific monitoring roles, refer to the GCP Monitoring Access Control documentation.
  2. Assign Roles Specifically: Use IAM predefined roles rather than primitive roles to assign more granular permissions. Predefined roles for monitoring include roles like roles/monitoring.viewer and roles/monitoring.editor. You can find detailed role definitions and their permissions in the GCP Monitoring Access Control documentation.
  3. Regularly Review IAM Policies: Conduct scheduled audits of IAM policies to ensure that granted permissions remain appropriate over time. Check for any unnecessary or excessive access that could potentially expose sensitive monitoring data.
  4. Use Custom Roles When Necessary: If predefined roles do not meet your precise needs, consider creating custom roles with specific permissions tailored to your organization's requirements. Further details on custom roles management can be found in the provided access control documentation.

For more information on managing access control in GCP Monitoring, including role definitions and best practices, refer to the official Monitoring Access Control documentation.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Monitor notification rates
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that notification limits, such as one notification every five minutes, are enforced in Google Cloud Monitoring, follow these steps:

  1. Access Alerting Policies: Start by navigating to the Google Cloud Console and select your project. Go to the Monitoring section, and under the Alerting option, review your alerting policies.

  2. Modify Notification Rate Limit: Open the specific alerting policy you wish to modify. Within the policy settings, look for the notification channels and rate limiting configuration. Set the desired rate limit to enforce the rule of 1 notification every 5 minutes.

  3. Enable Log-based Alerting (If applicable): If you're using log-based incidents, ensure that these alerts are configured to adhere to your rate limits by defining the conditions in the alert policy appropriately.

  4. Verify Configuration: After adjusting the rate limits, test your configuration to verify that notifications are sent according to the defined schedule.

For more information and detailed guidance on configuring alert policies and rate limits, refer to Google Cloud Monitoring: Log-based Incidents.

standard.ref: AU-5 Response to Audit Logging Process Failures
AU-6 Audit Record Review, Analysis, and Reporting
AU-7 Audit Record Reduction and Report Generation
DE.AE-2: Detected events are analyzed to understand attack targets and methods
DE.AE-3: Event data are collected and correlated from multiple sources and sensors
DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
DE.CM-7: Monitoring for unauthorized personnel, connections, devices, and software is performed
DE.DP-4: Event detection information is communicated

customField.value: AU-5 Response to Audit Logging Process Failures

countermeasure.name: Use longer retest windows in your conditions
countermeasure.desc:
To address the challenge of using a longer retest window in alerting policies, which can make them less responsive, consider implementing the following countermeasures:

  1. Optimize Alert Frequency: Adjust the alert frequency settings to ensure timely response. While a longer retest window can help to reduce alert noise, optimizing frequency settings allows you to maintain responsiveness by balancing between immediate alerts and actionable signals. For detailed configuration options, refer to the GCP Monitoring Alerts - Concepts In Depth.
  2. Utilize Multiple Conditions: Define multiple conditions in alerting policies to refine the criteria under which alerts are triggered. This approach can compensate for extended retest windows by ensuring alerts are only fired under clearly actionable scenarios. For guidance on setting up conditions, see Alerting Policy Concepts.
  3. Incorporate Labels: Use labels to categorize and prioritize alerts, which can help in managing and sorting alerts effectively. By appropriately labeling alerts, you ensure that important alerts are not overlooked despite a delayed retest period. Review the best practices for labels in Managing Alert Labels.
  4. Implement Log-Based Incidents: Leverage log-based incidents to gain insights from log data that can be configured to alert on specific log entries, enhancing incident response while dealing with longer retest windows. Detailed information on setting up these incidents can be found in Log-Based Incidents.

These steps aim to mitigate the potential downsides of using longer retest windows by enhancing the precision and effectiveness of your alerting policies. By combining these measures, you can optimize monitoring responsiveness and maintain security posture.

countermeasure.name: Verify synthetic monitor configurations
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the correct deployment and settings for synthetic monitors in GCP Monitoring, a cloud engineer should follow these steps:

  1. Create Synthetic Monitors:
    • Utilize the Google Cloud Console to initialize and configure synthetic monitors. This can be an essential step in proactively identifying and addressing potential issues in your application.
    • Refer to the official GCP documentation to create synthetic monitors effectively, ensuring the selection of appropriate protocols and geographic locations for comprehensive monitoring. See detailed instructions at Create Synthetic Monitors.
  2. Security Configuration:
    • Ensure that access to synthetic monitoring resources is controlled using Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles. Carefully assign roles to users, providing only the permissions necessary for their responsibilities. More information can be found at Access Control.
    • Additionally, review compliance and data handling practices for synthetic monitoring data to conform with security policies. This is crucial for maintaining governance over sensitive metrics and logs. Check further guidelines at Data Compliance.
  3. Monitor and Alert Configuration:
    • Set up alerting policies that align with your monitoring objectives. You can establish thresholds and conditions for triggering alerts to allow quick response to anomalies detected by synthetic monitors. Alerting policies specifics are available at Uptime Alerting Policies.

By following these guidelines, you can deploy synthetic monitors securely and effectively within GCP, ensuring robust visibility and timely response to potential issues in your infrastructure.

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Missing data impacts alerting
threat.desc:
General threat description
Missing time-series data can lead to interruptions in the continuity of monitoring, thus impacting the effectiveness of alerting policies in identifying and notifying incidents in real-time. This gap may cause security breaches to go unnoticed and unaddressed.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include technical failures, network interruptions, or issues in data ingestion pipelines that result in missing or delayed data. Improper configurations or insufficient access permissions can also lead to data not being collected or transmitted correctly.
Impacts
The primary impact is the potential for unmonitored security breaches. Without complete time-series data, security teams might not be alerted to incidents as they happen, increasing the risk of prolonged exposure to threats and potentially greater damage or data loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attack scenario could involve network failures leading to a temporary disconnect between data sources and the monitoring platform. During this period, an attacker could exploit a vulnerability within the infrastructure. Without alerts being triggered due to data gaps, the attack might remain active and undetected, resulting in data breaches or other malicious activities.

threat.name: Handling of unaddressed incidents
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to manage and address incidents effectively can result in prolonged service outages or unresolved security issues, potentially affecting the availability and security of cloud services.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include cloud administrators, incident response teams, or IT operations staff who fail to follow established incident management processes. Attack vectors can involve overlooked alerts, misconfigured monitoring tools, or inadequate communication during an incident.
Impacts
Potential impacts include extended downtime, loss of customer trust, financial penalties, and increased vulnerability to further attacks. Ineffective incident management can also lead to data breaches and compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An example scenario is when a cloud service experiences a security breach, but due to mismanaged incident response procedures, the breach goes unnoticed and unresolved for several days, causing data exposure and service disruptions. Another scenario could involve neglecting critical alerts from monitoring systems, leading to undetected downtime and customer dissatisfaction.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Log-based incident limitations
threat.desc:
General threat description
Overloading a monitoring system with an excessive number of log-based notifications can obscure significant incidents, potentially allowing them to go unnoticed.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors could intentionally create a flood of notifications by generating high volumes of non-critical logs, overwhelming the system and masking important events.
Impacts
Critical incidents might be missed due to the noise caused by the overabundance of notifications, leading to delayed responses and increased risk of successful attacks.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider configures the system to generate excessive logging for non-critical events, causing security teams to overlook a data breach occurring simultaneously.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499.002 - Service Exhaustion Flood

threat.name: High latency in uptime checks
threat.desc:
General threat description
Uptime checks with high response time can delay the detection of incidents and the subsequent delivery of alerts. This delay can ultimately affect the overall availability of services monitored through GCP Monitoring.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This issue can be caused by network latency, inefficient routing, or heavy computational loads that lead to extended response times from the services being monitored.
Impacts
Delays in alerting can result in prolonged service outages or degradations, as issues may not be addressed promptly. It can also lead to increased downtime and potentially a loss of trust from users relying on the monitored service.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization relies on uptime checks to monitor the health of its cloud-based applications. Due to high response times in these checks, a server outage goes undetected for several hours. Alert notifications are delayed, and the incident remains unresolved, leading to significant service disruption and loss of customer confidence.

threat.name: Synthetic monitor misconfigurations
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper configuration settings in synthetic monitoring tools can result in failure to alert on service downtimes.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents include negligent system administrators who configure monitoring tools incorrectly, leading to missed alerts. This can occur without any malicious intent but may also be exploited by certain insiders who may intentionally configure these monitors incorrectly to suppress alerts.
Impacts
The impacts of this include unrecognized failures in services leading to prolonged downtimes, loss of revenue, decreased customer trust, and ineffective service level agreements (SLAs).
Example Attack Scenarios
An administrator accidentally disables monitoring alerts in the synthetic monitoring configuration. As a result, a critical service experiences downtime for several hours, causing a breach in SLAs and significant financial losses for the company. Another scenario could involve an insider with access to monitoring tools intentionally misconfiguring them to hide the downtime of a service for which they are responsible, avoiding accountability.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insufficient access control
threat.desc:
General threat description
Weak IAM configurations can lead to unauthorized access, where unauthorized users gain access to sensitive and critical monitoring data within GCP Monitoring. This can occur due to improperly configured Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles and permissions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers or malicious insiders who exploit weak or misconfigured IAM policies. They may attempt to systematically test access control configurations or use phishing techniques to gain credentials that allow unauthorized access.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat can be severe, including unauthorized access to critical cloud resources or monitoring datasets, leading to potential data breaches, loss of sensitive information, or disruption of service operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an account with excessive permissions due to a misconfigured IAM policy and retrieves monitoring information that reveals system vulnerabilities. Another scenario could involve a former employee whose credentials are still active, using them to access and export sensitive data from GCP Monitoring.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breach risk from metadata insertion
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data could be inadvertently integrated into GCP Monitoring configurations, which might lead to accidental exposure to unauthorized parties.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Developers or DevOps engineers who misconfigure monitoring services or accidentally include sensitive data in logs or metrics. Incorporation of sensitive information into configuration files that are widely accessible within the organization.
Impacts
Potential exposure of confidential data, leading to data breaches, compliance violations, and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
A developer unknowingly embeds API keys, passwords, or personally identifiable information (PII) into monitoring configurations, which are then accessed by individuals without proper clearance, resulting in data leakage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552.005 - Cloud Instance Metadata API

weakness.name: CWE-1007
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1007: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

weakness.name: CWE-1037
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1037: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply Bucket Lock policies to enforce retention periods for stored objects
countermeasure.desc:
Apply Bucket Lock policies in GCP Storage to enforce mandatory retention periods on objects within storage buckets. This prevents any deletion or modification of data during the specified retention period. This security control is essential for protecting critical data from accidental deletions, overwrites, or unauthorized changes. Once configured, the retention period cannot be shortened or removed, offering robust protection for sensitive data that must comply with regulatory or legal retention requirements. Bucket Lock can also be combined with object holds to protect individual objects beyond the retention settings.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Bucket Lock Documentation

standard.ref: Business Continuity Management and Operational Resilience
DE.AE-3: Event data are collected and correlated from multiple sources and sensors

ID.AM-5: Resources (e.g., hardware, devices, data, time, personnel, and software) are prioritized based on their classification, criticality, and business value
ID.AM-6: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established
ID.BE-4: Dependencies and critical functions for delivery of critical services are established
ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.RA-4: Potential business impacts and likelihoods are identified
ID.SC-5: Response and recovery planning and testing are conducted with suppliers and third-party providers
PR.AT-5: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their roles and responsibilities
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.IP-10: Response and recovery plans are tested
PR.IP-4: Backups of information are conducted, maintained, and tested
PR.IP-8: Effectiveness of protection technologies is shared

RC.CO-3: Recovery activities are communicated to internal and external stakeholders as well as executive and management teams
RC.IM-1: Recovery plans incorporate lessons learned
RC.RP-1: Recovery plan is executed during or after a cybersecurity incident
RS.AN-2: The impact of the incident is understood
RS.AN-4: Incidents are categorized consistent with response plans
RS.CO-1: Personnel know their roles and order of operations when a response is needed
RS.CO-3: Information is shared consistent with response plans
RS.CO-4: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans
RS.IM-1: Response plans incorporate lessons learned
RS.RP-1: Response plan is executed during or after an incident

countermeasure.name: Configure signed URLs to provide time-limited access to storage objects
countermeasure.desc:
Configure signed URLs in GCP Storage to allow time-limited access to specific objects without exposing the entire bucket. Signed URLs provide a secure mechanism to grant temporary access to an object for a defined period, after which the URL expires and access is revoked. This is particularly useful for scenarios where you need to share objects with external users or systems in a controlled manner. By using signed URLs, you ensure that access to sensitive objects is restricted, protecting the storage bucket while still enabling authorized users to retrieve the needed files within a specified time frame.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Signed URLs Documentation

ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
ID.AM-4: External information systems are catalogued
ID.GV-4: Governance and risk management processes address cybersecurity risks

Methods for Submitting Requests to Delete Requests to Correct and Requests to Know (d)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Enable object versioning in GCP Storage buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Enable object versioning in GCP Storage to automatically retain prior versions of objects stored in buckets. This feature ensures that whenever an object is modified, deleted, or overwritten, the previous versions remain accessible for recovery. Object versioning is an essential safeguard against accidental deletions or modifications, allowing you to restore earlier versions of files when necessary. This feature is particularly useful in environments where multiple users or automated processes interact with the same objects, reducing the risk of permanent data loss due to human error or unexpected overwrites.

When object versioning is enabled, GCP Storage keeps track of object changes by assigning unique version identifiers to each version of an object. You can access, restore, or even delete specific object versions as needed. This can be configured at the bucket level, and it’s important to consider implementing version lifecycle management to control the storage cost of maintaining old versions by automatically deleting older versions based on your organization’s data retention policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Object Versioning Documentation

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

countermeasure.name: Use fine-grained access control for object-level permissions in GCP Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Leverage fine-grained access control to enforce more precise, object-level permissions within GCP Storage. Unlike bucket-level permissions, fine-grained control allows you to assign specific roles and access permissions directly to individual storage objects. This ensures that users and services only have the minimum required access to specific data, greatly reducing the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, or unintentional modifications. This is particularly useful for environments where different users or services need varying levels of access to objects within the same bucket. For instance, one user might need read access to a subset of objects, while another might require write permissions to other objects. By applying object-level roles, you can tailor security settings to align with your organization’s data protection policies, improving overall security and compliance.

Additionally, fine-grained access control integrates with Google Cloud IAM, allowing you to define roles and assign them based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring that users and services can only interact with data that they are authorized to access. It is also advisable to regularly review and audit permissions to ensure that access remains appropriate over time and does not violate security policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Fine-Grained Access Control Documentation

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion or overwrite of objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental deletion or overwrite of storage objects occurs when authorized users or automated processes inadvertently delete or overwrite important files. This can result in permanent data loss or corruption, impacting business continuity and potentially violating data retention policies.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Human error, misconfigured scripts, or processes with improper access rights can lead to accidental deletion or overwriting of data. Lack of backup or versioning policies exacerbates the risk.

Impacts

  • Loss of critical data leading to business disruptions.
  • Potential violation of data retention and compliance regulations.
  • Increased recovery costs due to the need for manual data restoration.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A developer accidentally deletes production data while performing routine maintenance due to incorrect permissions.
  2. A misconfigured automated backup script overwrites important storage objects with outdated or corrupted data.
  3. An employee accidentally overwrites a vital document in the storage bucket, resulting in the loss of an unversioned file without recovery options.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inappropriate access to storage objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inappropriate access to storage objects occurs when unauthorized users or services gain access to objects in GCP Storage. This could lead to unintended exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized modification, or deletion of critical data. Such access can result from misconfigurations in access control policies, excessive permissions, or lack of proper identity and access management controls.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigured Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, public exposure of buckets, or weak access control mechanisms. Insider threats, compromised service accounts, or overly permissive roles can also lead to inappropriate access.

Impacts

  • Data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of data.
  • Loss of trust, compliance violations, and potential financial loss.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A storage bucket is mistakenly configured with public access, allowing unauthorized users to access confidential company files.
  2. An internal employee with excessive permissions unintentionally deletes or modifies objects within a storage bucket.
  3. A compromised service account with access to storage objects is used by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Uncontrolled public access to objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Uncontrolled public access to storage objects occurs when storage buckets or objects are inadvertently configured to be publicly accessible. This can lead to unauthorized individuals being able to view, modify, or delete the objects, potentially exposing sensitive data or compromising business operations.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Misconfigured storage bucket permissions, over-permissive access settings, or lack of regular audits can result in public access. Attackers or external users can exploit such misconfigurations to access confidential or sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized parties.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of critical information.
  • Damage to reputation and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A company’s storage bucket is misconfigured to allow public access, resulting in confidential client data being accessible to anyone with the link.
  2. A developer mistakenly applies overly permissive access control policies to storage objects, leading to sensitive project data being accessed and leaked.
  3. An attacker scans for publicly exposed GCP Storage buckets and downloads proprietary files from an unsecured bucket.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized data modification
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized data modification occurs when storage objects are altered without proper authorization, leading to potential data corruption, integrity issues, or security breaches. This can result from misconfigured access controls, compromised accounts, or malicious insider activity.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers exploiting weak access control policies. Misconfigured permissions can provide unauthorized users with the ability to modify data.

Impacts

  • Data corruption or integrity loss.
  • Breach of confidentiality and trust.
  • Potential legal and compliance violations due to unauthorized data changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a poorly secured user account and modifies sensitive financial data stored in the cloud.
  2. A malicious insider alters critical operational data to disrupt business operations without proper authorization.
  3. An external attacker exploits misconfigured permissions to inject malicious data into a storage object, causing application failures.

weakness.name: CWE-1007
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1007: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

weakness.name: CWE-1037
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1037: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply Bucket Lock policies to enforce retention periods for stored objects
countermeasure.desc:
Apply Bucket Lock policies in GCP Storage to enforce mandatory retention periods on objects within storage buckets. This prevents any deletion or modification of data during the specified retention period. This security control is essential for protecting critical data from accidental deletions, overwrites, or unauthorized changes. Once configured, the retention period cannot be shortened or removed, offering robust protection for sensitive data that must comply with regulatory or legal retention requirements. Bucket Lock can also be combined with object holds to protect individual objects beyond the retention settings.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Bucket Lock Documentation

countermeasure.name: Configure signed URLs to provide time-limited access to storage objects
countermeasure.desc:
Configure signed URLs in GCP Storage to allow time-limited access to specific objects without exposing the entire bucket. Signed URLs provide a secure mechanism to grant temporary access to an object for a defined period, after which the URL expires and access is revoked. This is particularly useful for scenarios where you need to share objects with external users or systems in a controlled manner. By using signed URLs, you ensure that access to sensitive objects is restricted, protecting the storage bucket while still enabling authorized users to retrieve the needed files within a specified time frame.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Signed URLs Documentation

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Enable object versioning in GCP Storage buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Enable object versioning in GCP Storage to automatically retain prior versions of objects stored in buckets. This feature ensures that whenever an object is modified, deleted, or overwritten, the previous versions remain accessible for recovery. Object versioning is an essential safeguard against accidental deletions or modifications, allowing you to restore earlier versions of files when necessary. This feature is particularly useful in environments where multiple users or automated processes interact with the same objects, reducing the risk of permanent data loss due to human error or unexpected overwrites.

When object versioning is enabled, GCP Storage keeps track of object changes by assigning unique version identifiers to each version of an object. You can access, restore, or even delete specific object versions as needed. This can be configured at the bucket level, and it’s important to consider implementing version lifecycle management to control the storage cost of maintaining old versions by automatically deleting older versions based on your organization’s data retention policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Object Versioning Documentation

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

countermeasure.name: Use fine-grained access control for object-level permissions in GCP Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Leverage fine-grained access control to enforce more precise, object-level permissions within GCP Storage. Unlike bucket-level permissions, fine-grained control allows you to assign specific roles and access permissions directly to individual storage objects. This ensures that users and services only have the minimum required access to specific data, greatly reducing the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, or unintentional modifications. This is particularly useful for environments where different users or services need varying levels of access to objects within the same bucket. For instance, one user might need read access to a subset of objects, while another might require write permissions to other objects. By applying object-level roles, you can tailor security settings to align with your organization’s data protection policies, improving overall security and compliance.

Additionally, fine-grained access control integrates with Google Cloud IAM, allowing you to define roles and assign them based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring that users and services can only interact with data that they are authorized to access. It is also advisable to regularly review and audit permissions to ensure that access remains appropriate over time and does not violate security policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Fine-Grained Access Control Documentation

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion or overwrite of objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental deletion or overwrite of storage objects occurs when authorized users or automated processes inadvertently delete or overwrite important files. This can result in permanent data loss or corruption, impacting business continuity and potentially violating data retention policies.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Human error, misconfigured scripts, or processes with improper access rights can lead to accidental deletion or overwriting of data. Lack of backup or versioning policies exacerbates the risk.

Impacts

  • Loss of critical data leading to business disruptions.
  • Potential violation of data retention and compliance regulations.
  • Increased recovery costs due to the need for manual data restoration.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A developer accidentally deletes production data while performing routine maintenance due to incorrect permissions.
  2. A misconfigured automated backup script overwrites important storage objects with outdated or corrupted data.
  3. An employee accidentally overwrites a vital document in the storage bucket, resulting in the loss of an unversioned file without recovery options.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inappropriate access to storage objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inappropriate access to storage objects occurs when unauthorized users or services gain access to objects in GCP Storage. This could lead to unintended exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized modification, or deletion of critical data. Such access can result from misconfigurations in access control policies, excessive permissions, or lack of proper identity and access management controls.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigured Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, public exposure of buckets, or weak access control mechanisms. Insider threats, compromised service accounts, or overly permissive roles can also lead to inappropriate access.

Impacts

  • Data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of data.
  • Loss of trust, compliance violations, and potential financial loss.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A storage bucket is mistakenly configured with public access, allowing unauthorized users to access confidential company files.
  2. An internal employee with excessive permissions unintentionally deletes or modifies objects within a storage bucket.
  3. A compromised service account with access to storage objects is used by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Uncontrolled public access to objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Uncontrolled public access to storage objects occurs when storage buckets or objects are inadvertently configured to be publicly accessible. This can lead to unauthorized individuals being able to view, modify, or delete the objects, potentially exposing sensitive data or compromising business operations.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Misconfigured storage bucket permissions, over-permissive access settings, or lack of regular audits can result in public access. Attackers or external users can exploit such misconfigurations to access confidential or sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized parties.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of critical information.
  • Damage to reputation and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A company’s storage bucket is misconfigured to allow public access, resulting in confidential client data being accessible to anyone with the link.
  2. A developer mistakenly applies overly permissive access control policies to storage objects, leading to sensitive project data being accessed and leaked.
  3. An attacker scans for publicly exposed GCP Storage buckets and downloads proprietary files from an unsecured bucket.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized data modification
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized data modification occurs when storage objects are altered without proper authorization, leading to potential data corruption, integrity issues, or security breaches. This can result from misconfigured access controls, compromised accounts, or malicious insider activity.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers exploiting weak access control policies. Misconfigured permissions can provide unauthorized users with the ability to modify data.

Impacts

  • Data corruption or integrity loss.
  • Breach of confidentiality and trust.
  • Potential legal and compliance violations due to unauthorized data changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a poorly secured user account and modifies sensitive financial data stored in the cloud.
  2. A malicious insider alters critical operational data to disrupt business operations without proper authorization.
  3. An external attacker exploits misconfigured permissions to inject malicious data into a storage object, causing application failures.
